title: Big College or Small, You Can Find a Highly Ranked One
text:
Students often have strong feelings about the size of their ideal college—whether they want a cozy campus, a sprawling university or something in between. The good news is that there are plenty of highly ranked schools to fit any preference.

Small colleges say their tightknit communities give undergraduates special attention. More classes are taught by actual professors, not graduate students, and more people will know your name.

Explore the Full Rankings VIEW Interactive You can filter the WSJ/THE full rankings or customize them to focus on your own priorities.

Large colleges trumpet the vast resources, facilities and connections that come with an undergraduate enrollment in the tens of thousands. “It’s true, you’ll take a lot of classes at Berkeley with grad students and 500- to 600-person lectures, but you also get to take classes with Nobel Prize winners, Oscar winners, Pulitzer Prize winners,” says Bob Jacobsen, dean of undergraduate studies at the University of California, Berkeley, which has about 30,000 undergraduates and is ranked No. 34 overall in the Wall Street Journal/Times Higher Education College Rankings.

(You can sort the complete rankings by a variety of measures and reweight the main contributing factors to reflect what’s most important to you. Or you can compare two colleges here.)

In these rankings, the 100 largest colleges rank higher on average than the 100 smallest schools. But within the top tier of colleges, the split among sizes is almost even: The top 100 colleges overall include 33 small schools, defined as having undergraduate enrollments of 3,000 or less; 35 midsize schools, with enrollments between 3,001 and 10,000, and 32 large schools, with enrollments above 10,000.

Both larger and smaller schools have tried to overcome the negatives associated with their respective sizes. For instance, some smaller schools have found success by building a niche for themselves. Claremont McKenna College, with about 1,400 undergraduate students, emphasizes topics like government and finance emphasizes topics like government and finance while giving students access to a broad range of courses through the other schools in the Claremont Colleges consortium.. The school is ranked No. 38 overall.

“We don’t have 35 academic departments, we basically have 10 academic departments and they’re all exceptional,” says Dianna Graves, dean of students at Claremont McKenna.

In addition, one way extra attention paid to undergraduates at smaller schools can manifest itself is in higher graduation rates. Small schools scored 11% higher than large schools on average in the WSJ/THE rankings’ measure of graduation rates.

Some small, private colleges across the country struggle financially. Steve Sammons, vice president for strategic initiatives at Corban University, which is ranked below 600 overall and enrolls about 1,000 undergraduates, says funding “does become monumentally more difficult when you drop in enrollment below a 1,200 line.” But some high-profile, highly rated small schools, especially in the Northeast, have substantial funding. And large colleges are overwhelmingly public schools, which have their own financial challenges due to the limitations of government funding. Among the top 50 schools for resources, a measure that accounts for 30% of the overall WSJ/THE ranking, 14 are small and only five are large.

Attracting recruiters to campus can also be a challenge for small schools. Marci Linson, dean of admissions at the College of the Ozarks, ranked below 400 overall, says it’s hard to compete with schools that can offer tens of thousands of undergraduates to recruiters. “At a small school like ours you have a liberal-arts focus, so you may not have those name-brand large corporations knocking on the door every day,” says Dr. Linson.

Meanwhile, large colleges are brainstorming better ways to manage their students’ personal needs on a massive scale. The University of Central Florida, ranked 311th overall, uses a computer system to study trends in academic data in an effort to identify students in need of academic support or a change in degree track. With more than 48,000 undergraduates, the university has the largest enrollment of any school in the WSJ/THE rankings, a size that isn’t for everyone—like the size of the smallest school in the rankings, Clarke University, with fewer than 800 students.

“This comes down to what feels right for the student,” says Thad Seymour Jr., interim president of UCF.

Mr. O’Daly is a Wall Street Journal reporter. He can be reached at britton.odaly@wsj.com.
